Name: IQ Master
Description:
The players place their tokens on the start space.Each turn the players throw a die. If a 1 is thrown the player can move the pawn to the next field. When a player throws 2 - 5 the player takes a card from the pile. The player reads the question on the card aloud. The hourglass is turned and every player, including the player who had read the card, has 2 minutes to give the right answer. If a player knows the answer, he/she shouts 'stop.' When it is the correct answer that player may move its pawn to the next grey circle corresponding to the number on the card. Otherwise the player has to move backwards to the circle with the same number. If a 6 is thrown the player may choose a card from the pile.
When there is no time left and nobody has given the correct answer, then the next player starts its turn. The first player who reaches the last space, wins the game.

A variant of the game is to write down the answer and compare them when the time is up. All the players move their tokens forward or backwards.

Name: Kreativ Quiz
Description:
An unusual trivia Game, Kreativ Quiz combines 8 different questioning games into one. The themes you get asked about are:
Loose words
Knowledge of human nature
Nature and environment
Celebrities
Guess the profession
Knowing the world
Scribbling Stuff
Conundrums

Name: Trivial Pursuit: 50 Jahre Deutschland
Description:
Germany turned 50 in 1999 so thats a good reason to party!
1800 Questions (and Answers) from 1949 to 1999 are celebrating the History of East and West Germany.

Name: Trivial Pursuit: Kino Reise-Edition
Description:
A cinema-themed travel version of Trivial Pursuit, the most sold trivia game of all times. Can be played by 2 persons allone in the backseat of a car or in 2 teams (left and right side of a travelbus was nice :) )
Comes in a nice rigid plastic container.

Name: Harry Potter und der Stein der Weisen Halloween
Description: Two players reenact the scene from the movie "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" in which Harry and Wesley rescue Hermione from the Troll in the bathroom at Hogwarts.

Name: Da stimmt was nicht!
Description: Da Stimmt was Nicht! (Something is Wrong!) is an educational game based on the fairy tale "Snow White and the Seven Dwarves". The game includes a story book of the tale, and a set of cards that correspond to pages in the book. Players match the cards to the book pages and try to find the differences, and win one a wooden dwarf when they are the first to recognize the mistakes. A player wins when they collect two dwarves, but you can lose them too so the game as not as easy as it might sound! The components are excellent in the game as well.

Name: Unbridled Fury: Core
Description:
"Unbridled Fury is a set of miniatures rules for the fantasy genre which is designed from the ground up for skirmish battles. These small engagements and affrays are set in worlds as diverse as the players themselves (as well as the history of our very own Earth). It has no ‘official’ setting or miniatures line and allows the players to use whatever they want, in whatever setting they desire."

"Game-play is fast and brutal. The game is a departure from the regular approach to fantasy skirmish games - combat feels more like an all-out brawl rather than organized groups of fighters rolling dice at each other. You can almost feel the pain of the fighters as they hurl themselves into battle. Once the players get a grip on the rules games are usually over in under an hour, which is crucial to those who have to squeeze real life in between them. Physical space required is also
small - most 4’ x 4’ terrain boards are ideal; kitchen tables will suffice, though, and may even produce a tighter battle."

The rules were designed to be used with 28mm figures. "[O]ne figure represents one warrior, beast or frothing lunatic, so the effect of a single figure on the game is of great importance."

"Every figure has a profile, a set of equipment (weapons, armour, etc.) and possibly some 'special abilities.'" The profile for a figure consists of nine categories plus any special abilities. Special abilities include Berserker, Camouflage, Creature of Darkness, Fanatic, Flier, Giantslayer, Invisible, Musician, Night Vision, Teleporter, Undead, and Were-Creature.

The game includes rules on creating characters, companies, and setting up games using scenario creation tables. The game play covers areas such as command, morale, visibility, ambushes, cowardice, and fires.

Name: Mummbly
Description:
from the box front:
Mummbly
General Knowledge
A Game of Chance & Trivia

from the box back:
Roll the Dice,
Knock Down the Numbers,
Answer the Questions
& Score

from the manufacturer's website (www.mummbly.ca)
Mummbly Chance - This is a low score dice game that involves concealing a number or any one combination of numbers in the series according to the sum of the dice toss.
Mummbly Trivia - This is a high score trivia dice game that involves concealing a number or any one combination of numbers in the series according to the sum of the dice toss, and collecting valued trivia cards.

This game is very similar to Double Shutter. The game box starts with the numbers 1-9 flipped up. You roll two d6 and add them together. You then flip down enough numbers to add up to the total you rolled. Once you roll a number that can't be summed up by numbers still showing, you score by counting and summing these remaining numbers. This is the Mumbly Chance game. Mumbly Trivia adds Trivial Pursuit-like cards to the gameplay.

Name: Summit
Description:
Publisher's description:

To win the game you must be the first to reach the summit of this newly discovered 10,000 metre peak and score 100 points. Sounds simple! However, in this game of strategy you will need to navigate around moving obstacles and avoid capture by your opponents. Doubling, trebling and quadrupling may hasten your progress or send you tumbling down the mountain in all directions.

Name: Rules for the conduct of the war-game on a map 1896
Description:
British Army version of Kriegsspiel rules written in 1896.

Designed to be played with one or more umpires and several players per side.

Differs from the Prussian 1824 Krieggspiel by having the combat resolved by the umpire's judgment instead of the 1824 version's dice and combat tables.

Includes very useful tables containing march rates and frontage distances for military units just prior to WWI.

War Office rules for a game published originally in 1896. The rules are the clearest statement of the British Army´s understanding of the tactical realities on the battlefield pre-World War I
They highlight:

    The dubious nature of bayonet charges
    The value of trenches
    The necessary for artillery to engage from beyond rifle range
    Rates of march
    etc.


The War Game is intended to afford a representation of military maneuvers. It is played on a map drawn to a large scale, the troops engaged being indicated by small metal blocks, coloured Red for one force, Blue for the other.

The game needs at least two players (one for Red and the other for Blue) and an Umpire, but can easily accommodate more players in either side or as the Umpire's Assistants. Also is suggested to have an officer who would describe the game in play for a later memorandum

Name: Dial & Learn
Description:
Dial & Learn is an educational trivia game which uses a mechanical dialer to verify answers to common educational trivia questions. Categories include "The World of Science", "Lands and Seas", etc.

Recommended Ages 7 - 12

Contents:
Magic Dialer
Scorecards
Special marking pencil
Question cards
Rule Book

Name: KABILA Genial
Description:
It's a game of mental agility and competition which objective is to accumulate the most points along the 20 rounds. 
Each round has two different games, the first one called "Prueba de vocabulario" (vocabulary test) in which players will have to find the longest word using 9 given letters. Players randomly draw letter tiles asking for either a vowel or a consonant, there are also some "joker" cards that can work as any letter. The second game is called "Prueba de cálculo" (math test) in which players will have to get as close as possible to a number generated randomly with 3 dices (number between 1 to 999) using for it just 6 numbers. Players randomly draw number tiles asking for either a unit (1-9) or a decimal (10-90).

Allows from 2 to 6 players (12 if played in teams).

Name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition Café Jacques Vabre
Description:
Limited edition of Trivial Pursuit for the French coffee brand Jacques Vabre.
Contains
1 board
1 dice
6 round meepled
36 colored triangles (to fit into the meeples)
396 cards with questions

Categories:
blue: production
pink: coffee tasting
yellow: history and legends of coffee
brown: the brand Jacques Vabre
green: coffee producing countries
orange: green coffee

The rules are similar to the classical Trivial Pursuit.
The question are all coffee related and quite difficult.
This game was never sold in shops but distributed by the coffee brand for promotion.

Name: That's Life
Description: At the beginning of the play each player specifies purposes in life for itself its, in whom he distributes at least 250 points on the different columns (social, career, luck, education and wealth). This is valid to reach it now in the play. Each player can contain questions, have their answer different effects to the markers of the purposes in life or also simple instructions to shift the markers. Some fields of the programme are barriers, which only to be overcome to be able, if appropriate values were reached with certain purposes in life. Who met its targets at the best one, the play wins.

Name: Multimatch III
Description:
Multimatch I and II deals with square tiles, while  Multimatch III and IV concerns triangular tiles. 
The box of Multimatch III  contains a plastic hexagonal trail, and an acrylic set of MacMahon's Four-Color triangles. All 24 triangles are divided into three equal triangles (with short edges joining the centre to the corners) coloured with 4 colors.
The 1991 edition Kadon rulebook contains a large section of puzzles, and rules for 3 games, plus variants.

The games are:
Multimatch. Players take turns placing tiles on the hexagonal trail. The first piece placed on a border of the board determines the color of that border. Last player wins.
Outmatched. Players divide the tiles equally (face-down) and then race to assemble their group into a symmetrical shape, with tile edges matching.
Closure. The tiles are assembled into a random (but edge-matching) group. Players take turns "closing" one of the 3 colors by moving as few tiles as possible. Closing a color requires leaving no exposed edges of that color. Moves may not separate any tiles from the group.

Name: LIMITE 10
Description:
The game of the 10 clues.
The players must guess the secret word on the card with as few clues as possible, the fewer number of clues needed to guess the word the more spaces your team can move. The board consists in a track, the first player or team on go around for ten times wins the game.

Components:
- 500 cards
- 1 board
- 12 player pieces

Name: Artist: The Game
Description:
"For anyone who has ever dreamed of being among the collectors and the collected... Of organizing the openings and celebrating the sales... Of starving artists in a garret for the sake of the muse... But be warned: in the game, as in life, it takes more than talent to win. Anyone can play Artist - but, it's only the right combination of cash, canvases, contacts, and conniving that will make you a success!"

The first edition states that it was limited to 2000 copies.

Components include a game board styled after an artist's palette, instructions, a pad of Resume Score Sheets, cards, play money, and plastic discs.

Name: The Game of Africa
Description:
"New, Fascinating, Instructive. The Game of Africa, or Contest of the Search Expeditions."

"Three games in one. Any number can play. Amuses. Educates without study. Contains Expeditions, Playing-Board, Map, 64 Cards, comprising authentic biographies, history, geography. Sold by booksellers, etc., or sent, post paid, on receipt of price, $1.00."

Name: Googlepoly
Description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

In this version of Monopoly the goal is to organize the world

Name: Zombie Fluxx: Flame-Thrower Expansion Pack
Description:
Expansion for Zombie Fluxx which contains the Flame-Thrower Keeper and six new Zombie Creeper cards.

Part of the Fluxx series.

Expands

    Zombie Fluxx

Name: Cube Anagrams
Description: An antique word game played using five wooden cubes (dice) marked with letters. The other components include two wooden dice cups and a rules sheet. The game came in a colorful 7.5 x 4 x 2 inch box marked: "Fun for old and young. Exciting new letter game." And the instructions tout: "The most popular of all Letter Games."

Name: Summum
Description:
Summum is an abstract strategy game for 2 persons. The players take turns placing pieces on the colorful board trying to form one of three patterns. Players have to decide whether to score points or prevent the opponent for scoring points.
When one of the three patterns is formed the player scores points based on the pattern and the color of the rectangle on which the last piece of the pattern is placed.
The game ends when both players played their last piece.
The kings on the side of the board keep track of the score.

Contents
36 white pieces
36 black pieces
2 kings
1 board
rules

For more infomation visit: http://www.magi-games.nl/sum/index_sum.html (Dutch)

Name: Jack and Jill Target Game
Description: This is a simple shoot and hit the target type of game from Cadaco Ellis that was produced in 1948.

Name: Which Is It?
Description:
"The New Game of Which Is It? Bird, Beast, or Fish? Speak Quick or Pay."

An antique card game consisting of a deck of 52 cards colorfully depicting a variety of birds, fish, and other animals. Each card is marked with a number (5, 10, 15, or 20, and one 50.) The 50 point card is "Mr. Crowley", described in the rules as the famous Chimpanzee who for many years delighted children at the New Your City Zoo in Central Park.

There are two game variations. The game play revolves around playing a card when its name as read from a story in the rulebook. Points are scored according to the numbers on the cards.

Card manifest: 18 bird cards, 16 fish cards, 18 cards with other animals. The game also included a box and a rules booklet.

Name: Little Red Bushy Tail
Description:
This game is essentially a roll-and-move race game for 2 to 4 players, but instead of using dice, a series of tiles with movement numbers are drawn from a face-down pile. The board illustrates events in the story of Little Red Bushy Tail, a popular children;s story of the time.

Contents:

Board
Draw Tiles
4 player pieces
Instruction Booklet

Name: Game of Radio
Description:
"As Interesting as Radio Itself. Rules For The Three Great New Cards Games Broadcasting, Radio, Radio Junior (For Children.) Easy to Learn. A Riot of Clean, Fascinating Fun. The Best Family Game in Years. For Adults, For Children, For Parties. Everybody Likes Them."

A custom card game consisting of a sleeved card box, a 16 page rules booklet, and 48 cards. The cards are marked with the call signs and frequencies of vintage radio stations for twelve cities: WDAF in Kansas City, WCCO in St Paul-Minneapolis, KDKA in East Pittsburgh, WEAF in New York, WFAA in Dallas, WGY in Schnectady, KFI in Los Angeles, KFOA in Seattle, WOO in Philadelphia, KYW in Davenport, Iowa, and KYW in Chicago.  Three games are included; Broadcasting (which is an Old Maid variant), RADIO (which is a rummy variant), and Radio Junior (also a rummy variant).

Name: Rally Point Volume 2: Advanced Squad Leader Starter Kit Special Study
Description:
Rally Point Volume 2 is an ASL/ASL Starter Kit Compatible scenario pack from the Tampa ASL Group. Each scenario is fully compatible with full ASL rules and ASL Starter Kit Rules. These 10 scenarios were playtested with consideration for both rules sets and are presented in the Schwerpunkt easy-to-read format on high-quality cardstock.

ASL players need boards t, u, v, w, x, y, and z to play these scenarios. ASL Starter Kit Players need Starter Kits 1, 2, and 3 to play the scenarios. This edition of Rally Point is intended to unite ASLers and ASL Starter Kit players through a common set of scenarios.


    RPT11 Butchers And Bakers: The Welsh Regiment attacks a small German infantry detachment on board y. This a 5.5 turn, all infantry, tournament level scenario. 



    RPT12 Retreat From Bairak: The German 429th Infantry Division, covered by PzIII's, withdraw under pressure from the Russian 169th Infantry Division and its supporting KV-1 M41 and T-34 tanks. This 5.5 turn scenario uses boards y and z. 



    RPT13 A Handful Of Howdy: American's from the 84th Infantry Division attack to clear a reinforced German machine gun platoon from the board v and x hills/buildings near Wegberg, Germany in this 4.5 turn, all infantry, tournament action. 



    RPT14 Keitel And Cox: CECINA, Italy, 1 July 1944: Sherman tanks supporting the 34th Infantry Division attack SS Panzer Grenadier Division 16 and a Tiger tank in this 4.5 turn thriller, set on board z. 



    RPT15 Comrade Klimenkov: OGLENDUV, Poland, 13 August 1944: This heavy-metal East Front action features Panzer Division 16 and its supporting Tiger tanks defending against IS-2M tanks and Russian infantry in this medium-sized, 6.5 turn, combined arms action set on boards u and v. 



    RPT16 Miracle At Sinagoga: SINAGOGA, Italy, 16 May 1944: This 6.5 turn action features two companies of British infantry and Sherman tanks in a combined arms attack against Germans from the 15th Panzer Grenadier Division. With a FlaK 18, mortars, assault guns, and PzIVs, this medium-sized scenario has plenty of replay value and lots of room to maneuver on boards t, v, and w. 



    RPT17 Hetzer Hunters: DURBOSLAR, Germany 19 November 1944: The 246th Volksgrenadier Division attacks with a company of infantry and three Hetzers to clear the American 116th Infantry Regiment from the key terrain on boards u and w in 5.5 turns. 



    RPT18 Worker's Settlement No. 8: Brian Williams designed this 5.5 turn tournament-level scenario that features a Russian infantry company and a T-34 M41 attacking elements of the German 227th Infantry Division with a Pak 38, defending on boards x and y. 



    RPT19 Mercury Rising: Hugh Downing penned this 6.5 turn gem that has an Allied force of New Zealand and Greek Infantry defending on boards v and y, verses a two-pronged German infantry attack. 



    RPT20 The Trouble With Tigers: Pete Shelling rounds out Rally Point #2 with an old fashioned Eastern Front, heavy metal slug-match. This baby has a company of German infantry, King Tigers, PzIVJs and assault guns attacking Russian infantry and their 122mm guns. Boards v, x, and z, provide lots of room to maneuver, while the reinforcing Russian IS-2s and T-34/85s make this scenario an exciting combined arms action.
Families: Game: Advanced Squad Leader Starter Kit

Name: BattleTech: Tactical Operations
Description:
Take your warfare to a whole new level of excitement! Deploy under cover of exotic weather and severe planetary conditions. Surprise your enemy with your mastery of new battlefield tactics—from artillery to command-level comms to minefields— as well as cutting-edge, prototype technologies! A daring commander can take advantage of any or all of these….if he’s brave enough to seize the moment! 
 Tactical Operations is the one-source reference for advanced rules that apply to on-world operations. It includes new movement and combat options, an extensive Advanced Weapons and Equipment section, and the rules for playing and constructing advanced Support Vehicles and Mobile Structures.

Expands:

    Classic Battletech: Total Warfare

Name: Cyber Tactics
Description: Cyber Tactics is a Trading Card Game for 2 or more players. Each player is known as a Navigator and they possess decks called the Hard Drive. Navigators draw Data Cards from their Hard Drives and Downloads them into the computerized world of Virtua to engage in combat. The objective is to destroy your opponent's Memory Core before he destroys your own.

Name: Eye of the Idol
Description:
The box contains all you need to seek the Eye of the Idol, a fabulous gem of legendary repute:

- a role play adventure taking you through the depths of an unmapped jungle (solo play)
- the rules for a fantasy game set on the island of the idol (for solo or group play)
The game board is built into the box and there is a small cut out area where the dice, counters and rules are stored.

Name: Squelch!
Description:
Squelch! is two games in one. They are:

Rain forest adventure board game:  Roll the dice and move your counter around the game board, following directions to move yourself and others forward and back.

Treasure hunt:  Hunt for specific animals and plants on the board and answer questions about them.

Name: The World Cup Game:  Expansion Set 4
Description:
The World Cup Game - Expansion 4 is now available and includes 4 more boards to add another angle to your World Cup experience.

This expansion set will include W.GERMANY 1974, ARGENTINA 1978, SPAIN 1982, USA 1994. These will be printed over 4 A3 boards along with 3 pages of rules additions and modifications for these particular tournaments. A scoresheet is included for each World Cup in the set.

Expands:

     The World Cup Game

Name: Les fractions
Description:
The box contains two dices with ratios on their faces, several coloured sectors of disk; and rings which you can clip the sectors onto. The different proportions used are : 1/2 ; 1/3 ;1/4 ; 1/6 and 1/8.

At his turn, each player throws the two ratio dices and picks up the disks sectors accordingly to the results. Then he tries to arrange those sectors around his rings, in order to form two perfect circles, and wins if he succeeds in this task. Otherwise, the winner is he who has the most rings completes, or else the most sectors.

Three different variants of growing difficulties are proposed, allowing players to make use of different levels of math abilities from adding fractions to basic probabilities.

Name: Par Out Golf
Description:
In Par Out Golf, two armchair golfers from Chico decided to swap traditional golf clubs and balls for wet-erase markers, ink, and a richly illustrated and laminated 18-hole championship game board course. By doing so they made golf portable (think family vacations, road trips and even around the office), accessible and incredibly easy to learn, even for someone who has never stepped foot on a real fairway.

Par Out Golf is challenging, exciting and incredibly unique, playing as inconsistently as the real sport thanks to a twist you'll never "see" coming! It puts you and your family in the middle of the action, competing in stroke play, match play, or one of the many variations that will continue to challenge and entertain round after round.

Best for ages 5 and up and from 1 to 4 players, Par Out Golf is filled with lighthearted competition as players shoot for the lowest score through the 18 stunningly illustrated holes on the course. Game play is easy to learn for the amateur or junior golfer, and still challenging for the pro requiring a strikingly similar level of skill and focus on every shot.

Best of all, this course can be played again and again! A simple wipe with a damp cloth is all it takes to get the greens and fairways ready for another round.

Par Out Golf is played on a set of spiral bound, laminated pages. Special "wet-erase" markers are used so the line is easy to draw, won't smudge, and very easy to erase. The rules are very, very close to the game of golf, complete with sand and water traps, obstacles and slopes. So close is it to "real" golf, you can play each of five classic variations of golf: stroke play, match play, tombstone play, and pro play.

Of the several skills you practice while playing Par Out Golf, a fascinating, and, to any golf player, significant challenge is learning how to visualize your shot. The more observant you are, the more capable you are at remembering the lay of the land, the more effectively you can imagine the exact amount of drive to put on the ball, the better you'll do. This, of course, is the essence of Par Out Golf. Like "real" golf, Par Out Golf challenges both mind and body. If you want to know more about the physical and cognitive aspects of the game, take a look at the thoughtfully written essay: Par Out Science 101 at www.paroutgolf.com.

If you want, you can practice on the Driving Range (on another page) or use the 19th hole (on yet another page) to design your own. You can add your own obstacles, changing the difficulty of each hole, essentially making the game something you can play for-just-about-ever.

Par Out Golf is recommended for 1 to 4 players (it comes with four different wet-erase markers). If you must try before you buy, you can download the first three holes online.

Name: Dragon's Journey: A Race to Save the Magic
Description:
Imagine a world where the Magic is dying.  Where dragons and wizards are forced into hiding as their numbers dwindle.  But the Spirit of Magic gives a final push to save itself and six brightly colored dragon babies are born to powerful parents.  All the creatures in Ohadi, a magical land of majestic mountains, rolling rivers and forbidden forests, must work together to teach the babies their dragon skills before the Magic disappears forever.

Be the first dragon to earn all 5 Dragon Skill cards, receive a dragon name, collect each of the 3 treasures from the King's Castle, and return to the cave.

Each player plays a dragon moving around the board collecting various items and avoiding spaces that deter progress.

Name: Tools Of The Trade
Description:
The Tools of the Trade game introduces children to 32 different occupations and the tools they use as the kids sort pictures into the correct trays.

Includes 4 category boards, 56 colorful tiles, and a red plastic tray.

Smethport Model No. 8301

Designed to be enjoyed by 1 or 2 players Ages 4 - 8.

Name: Zwort's Nature Report Animal Adventure
Description:
Players explore the arctic, desert, forest, jungle, ocean, and safari habitats with Zwork, a curious reporter from outer space. As children play the game they improve their vocabulary, thinking skills, and listening skills.

Includes a colorful board, tokens, cards, and question booklet.

(c)1991 Thinking Well

ISBN 1-55999-203-4

Name: Domino Squares
Description:
Each domino square is a double domino. Instead of two parts, each has four. Play can play all of the standard domino games like Block, Draw and Mexican Train, or play the exclusive new "Domino Squares" game. Includes 45 Domino Square dominoes (equivalent to 90 regular dominoes), scorepad and rules.

From the publisher's website:

Winning Moves Games takes dominoes to a new dimension with Domino Squares. They’re twice the size of regular dominoes for double the fun–and players score on every turn (score sheets provided). Enjoy playing Domino Squares!

The pieces found in Domino Squares have four advantages over common dominoes:

1. Each is a "double domino" – a large square comprised of four smaller squares (like two rectangular dominoes joined together).

2. Some pieces cause actions to occur. These are called "Command" pieces and contain words or phrases like "Skip" and "Draw 1".

3. Pieces can be played with more variety. You may play a piece that matches any of the three open-sides of either "end" piece on the layout.

4. Scoring occurs on every turn. After it is played, points are awarded for the "scoring side" of a piece (its two unmatched squares.)

Name: Trusts and Busts or Frenzied Finance
Description:
This game is a vivid representation of stock speculation as carried on by the general public through the brokers' offices of Wall Street.  The uncertainties of the game and the anxiety of the players to be on the right side of the "Market," together with the possible occurrence of a "Boom" or a "Slump" give to the game the power to call up every emotion that sways the real speculator in stocks.

Parts:

86 cards with the following values -
  60 cards representing "value" cards (6 sets of 10 cards with numbers on them)
  13 "Trust" cards 
  16 small "Market" cards the represent the different occurrences

Name: Game of Buy and Sell
Description:
Game of store or buying merchandise with with money.  The object of the game is to buy as much merchandise as you can before all the cards are gone.

Money is 1 cent up to $20.

Merchandise includes flour, mackerel, corn meal, umbrella, envelopes, pineapple, beef, tea, stove, pickles, sugar, skates, apple, whistle, cheese, chickens, gum, eggs, coal, Lion coffee, hat, honey, tennis rackets and other items.

Name: Wild Animals of North America
Description: This game sponsored by the National Wildlife Federation in Washington was edited by famed naturalist Roger Tory Peterson. The box says that it was illustrated by America's foremost Nature Artists. It is a trivia type game with questions and information about many wild animals including;  Grizzlie Bears, Raccoons, Otters, Sheep, Buffalo and even Chipmunks.

Name: Elementaire
Description:
"An instructive game teaching the rudiments of music."

The components include a box, rules folder, musical note cards, and 96 numbered squares (blue and pink).

Name: Game of By Mail, Express, or Accommodation Train; or Interstate Commerce
Description:
Each players has a locomotive which journeys to destinations across the United States seeking to buy the most valuable commodities. The game ends when ten trips have been completed by one of the players. The winner is the player who obtained commodities having the highest total value.

The game components include the box, a game board depicting an "accurate, up-to-date" map of the United States and its chief railway lines, a set of four wooden discs representing locomotives, two "indicators" (spinners) marked 1-12, and a set of cards bearing the names of states, cities, commodities and their prices.

Name: Flat Acting
Description:
Now available for purchase!  Check with your friendly local game store or order direct at www.flatacting.com.

Uh oh... bedlam has broken out at the Eye-Level Entertainment movie studio!  The studio only has enough money to make one movie.  When word of that gets out, all the genres begin a battle to make sure that movie stars them!

Flat Acting is a family-friendly strategy game where each player assumes control of a different movie genre or the movie crew.  Players place and/or move game pieces around a modular game board to try and control the different parts of the movie set.  At the end of the game, the player who controls the largest portion of the movie set wins.  Roll cameras!

Name: Hoop-La!
Description:
An antique tabletop dexterity game where they players score points by flipping weighted paper cones into a 7x7 grid of scoring holes punched into an insert for the bottom half of the box. Beneath each hole is a number indicating the number of points scored for each cone that goes in the hole. The scores range from 5 points around the edges of the box to 50 points for the center hole. Each player takes a turn dropping the twelve cones onto the board one at a time. The first player to reach 100 points wins.

The components include the game box, a set of twelve weighted cones, and a set of flippers. The instructions are printed inside the lid of the 12.5 x 12.5 x 2.25 inch box. The colorful cover art depicts two clowns juggling cone shapes hats back and forth.

The publication date is an estimate.

Name: Napoleon in Italy
Description:
Napoleon in Italy is a simple two-player strategy game of maneuver and combat that simulates a portion of the campaign in November 1796 between the Austrians and the French in northern Italy.  Players move their forces and have combat across the map in an effort to occupy key areas at the end of the game.

The game, published in Issue #3 (Spring 2008) of Panzer Digest, comes with a mapsheet, set of unit counters and markers, and rules (printed within the magazine).  The map represents a portion of northern Italy where the original campaign was conducted.  Movement on the map is regulated via a series of areas, usually representing towns.  Areas that are connected by a line are adjacent to one another.  There are no terrain effects in the game, and any one area is the same as any other, though some areas are designated with a star to represent victory areas.

French and Austrian units represent divisions, and each combat strength point represents approximately 1000 men.  Units take losses in combat by marking off lost strength points from a unit roster.  The overall commanders, Napoleon for the French and Alvinczy for the Austrians, are also represented by counters.  Napoleon has a number of special benefits, to help balance the massive numerical advantage of the Austrian army.

Before the game begins, players bid the number of victory points they claim they can earn playing the Austrians, and the player with the highest bid must earn at least that many to win.  Each turn represents three days of campaigning, and the game lasts six turns.  Playing time is about 20 minutes solitaire, about 45-90 minutes against an opponant.

Name: The News Boy Game
Description:
An antique 'spin and move' style children's racetrack game where the players race to be the first newspaper boy to travel 79 spaces to reach the Large Store end space. Special spaces along the way can cause a player's pawn to advance or go backwards.

The game components include the box, a spinner, and four wooden pawns. The illustrated game board is printed on the inside of the box bottom. The concise rules (five sentences long) are printed around the outside edge of the game board.

Name: LaRue
Description:
Larue is a tile placement game in which players alternately place triangular tiles on a board such that at least one edge colour matches that of an adjacent tile.  The object of the game is to be the first player to have placed all of their tiles.

The game comes in brightly coloured box with the (brief) rules printed on the back of the box.  Contents are: A card game board about 28cm square to which is stuck a card border enclosing a 24cm square play area; and 72 right-angled isosceles triangular tiles, each displaying three coloured sections.  All the card components are about 2mm thick are fairly well made.

There is a solo version suggested whereby the player attempts to fit all the pieces into the playing area (while observing the tile placement rule)

Name: Deathsville Assassin The Board Game
Description:
“The President is about to start a tour of Deathsville, despite warnings from a known terrorist group that an attempt will be made on his life. Deathsville’s finest law enforcement officers have vowed to protect the President throughout the tour and to hunt out any possible threats.

As a member of the Deathsville Police Department you must use search warrants to look for assassins, before the President encounters them. However with all the usual red tape getting in the way, even acquiring the necessary search warrants may take some time.

To make matters worse, it appears that a member of the Police Department is working with the terrorist and will not rest until the President is dead... let the tour commence!”

Deathsville Assassin is an exciting Print and Play board game for 3 to 6 players.

Players move around the game board searching for Assassins, but one player will secretly be working with the terrorists and must plot to ensure that the President does not survive his tour of Deathsville.

All the files needed to enable you to Print and Play this game are available from the site below. You will need to provide a 6 sided die.

http://www.wargamedownloads.com/item.php?item=714&pics

Name: Bag of Fun
Description: This is a vintage game from 1932. The object of the game is for players to pull a number out of a bag and then match the number with numbers in a game book which lists different actions that must then be accomplished in order to score points. (some of the tasks that might be chosen are to "Sing a song and then have the rest of the players join in with the chorus" or "Have your eyes blindfolded and kiss the one you are with.")

Name: Vive L'Empereur:  Grand Tactical Miniatures Rules for Napoleonic Warfare
Description:
Vive L'Empereur is a miniatures game for simulating large battles in the Napolonic era with small numbers of figures and smaller tables.  The game is designed for 15mm figures with 1 figure = 100 men and a ground scale of 16" = 1 mile.  Each turn represents 30 minutes.  The basic unit of maneuver is the regiment/brigade or the artillery battery.  Unit losses are kept on a roster.

Base width sizes for the game is determined by figure density:

two-rank infantry:  1 figure/10mm
three-rank infantry:  1 figure/7mm
cavalry:  1 figure/18mm
artillery:  5mm/gun (typically 6)

Sequence of play:
A. Roll for Initiative
B. Announce Full Moves
C. Announce Close Combat Attempts
D. Move Units
E. Fire Artillery and Musket Volleys
F. Fire Skirmisher Shots
G. Make Any Close Combat and Morale Checks
H. Take Close Combat Morale Losses
I. Perform Engineering Operations
J. Rally Units

Name: Lou Gehrig Plaball
Description:
The game comes with an 18" X 18" square baseball field.  There is a metal spot located at the batters box which will expel your ball bearing or marble ball into the playing field. The ball will land in some position which will result in the determination of what happens on the particular at bat. (thanks to berniethepicker at Ebay)

The wording at the batter's box on the board is: 
           "Lou Gehrig"
             Official
  by arrangement with Christy Walsh
             PLABALL

Name: Fame and Fortune Game
Description:
"Fame & Fortune: Win Fame while you gather a Fortune!" In this Whitman game, players use a spinner to move along a convoluted track that includes gender-specific career tracks [for girls, nurse, actress, stewardess, secretary, housewife and teacher; for boys: star athlete, jet pilot, cowboy, fireman, explorer, and scientist) and a "luck track" to collect "lucky gold coins." Whomever reaches the end of the track ["the pot of gold"] with the most gold wins [yet another life-lesson for kids].

Though the game is undated, based on the logo style, it would appear the game dates to the early 1960s.

Name: Multimatch IV
Description:
Multimatch I and II deals with square tiles, while  Multimatch III and IV concerns triangular tiles. 
The box of Multimatch IV contains a plastic hexagonal trail, and an acrylic set of Trioker four-colour triangles. Instead of showing dots, the triangles corners are coloured in plain colours.
The 1994 edition Kadon rulebook contains a large section of puzzles, and rules for 3 games, plus variants.  The two first games are the same that those of Multimatch II.
Multimatch. Players take turns placing tiles on the hexagonal trail. Edges must match and the first piece must be placed on a border. Last to play wins.
Outmatched. Players share the tiles at random and then race to assemble their group into a symmetrical shape, with edges matching.
Hexagonal Match. The four solid-colour tiles are set as starter pieces. Players draw tiles and play them at their turn trying to complete a 6 tiles hexagon.

Name: Heist
Description: Heist is a card game depicting the efforts of a modern band of thieves to pull off a major caper. Recruit members to your gang and accumulate the right set of skills to pull it off. Mess with your opponents Jobs or trade with them to get the skills you need.

Name: Merge
Description: Through open auctions and raids, players buy and merge companies.  When all four companies of a group are acquired, points are awarded.  Play continues until all 10 sets are complete, after which the player with the most points wins.

Name: Crayola "Draw What?"
Description: Players form two teams.  A member of the active team receives a noun, a verb and an adjective (eg BANANA LAUGHING BIG) and using crayons, has one minute to draw a scene incorporating all three words.  Acting (without words or sound effects) can be used if the verb is too difficult to draw.  If the other members of the team can guess all three words, they receive a point.  The first team to five points wins.

Name: Bigtopolis
Description:
"Circus owners compete for the best cities and touring acts in their quest to conquer the big top." Inspired by Monopoly.

Components: game board, rules folder, play tips sheet, play money, city license cards, railroad operator cards, fortune cards, touring act cards, ticket price calculator, pawns, and dice.

Name: Staggers
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Easy to learn….hard to put away!
Just one round and you’ll be hooked!

Introduction

Staggers is a low-intensity social dice game involving two or more players. The object of the game is to score the most points possible during each turn. Players score points when a die or dice combination matches one or more numbers on the field of play. Players use glass markers to cover those numbers as they compete.

Game in a Nutshell

The first player rolls three dice onto the field of play, called the leather , then uses glass markers ( paddy flats , or flatties ) to cover numbers that match an individual die or dice combination (see Basic Roll). A turn ends when a player is topped —unable to use all three dice to cover one, two, or three numbers on the leather . On the final roll of a turn, a player is allowed to cover as many numbers as possible, even if all of the dice cannot be played. At the end of each turn, points are added up and recorded by the scorekeeper. The dice are then passed to the next player.

Players must always roll three dice. If a roll results in stacked or cocked dice, including those cocked against a flattie , all three must be rolled again.

The player with the most accumulated points wins the match.

Basic Roll 
Dice can be added together or played as naturals. For example, a 2 , 4 , 5 roll offers five options:

Cover the 2 , 4 , and 5 .

Cover the 6 [2 + 4] and the 5 .

Cover the 9 [4 + 5] and the 2 .

Cover the 7 [2 + 5] and the 4 .

Cover the 11 [2 + 4 + 5].

This is just an overview….

You will also learn how to score the game. The 6 basic dice rolls. The Lexicon of Staggers, and much more.

Name: Frontline General: Italian Campaign Introduction
Description:
Frontline General: Italian Campaign Introduction introduces players to the Frontline General 'Land, Air, & Sea Tabletop Simulation', an Operational and Tactical Level WWII Consim.  The system covers Land, Air, and Sea wargaming mostly at the Operational level with a tactical 'feel'.  The Campaign may optionally be used to 'drive' more detailed tabletop miniatures battles for decisive engagements.  Miniatures combat expands on the level of detail.

A basic Economic and Supply System challenges players to choose and supply an effective balance of Units for the objectives at hand.  Event and Command Cards provide more options during the game.  Team Play Command allows players to split turn responsibilities among a General and subordinate Commanders.

The introductory version of the 'Southern Italy Campaign' is the first release in a series and is available as a production version and free via Print & Play.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Our National Ball Game
Description:
An antique baseball game played on a wooden board which depicts a baseball field. The rules and a die rolling chart are also printed on the board. The board is approximately 20x20 inches. The other components include a pair of dice and a set of markers used to represent base runners.

The game is played using a chart which determines the results of each pitch by rolling two six-sided dice. The chart lists each pair of numbers that could be thrown and gives a result for each pairing. The results include a base hit, a "two base hit", "three base hit", getting on base by error, getting on base by balls, one strike, foul out, out at first, fly out, double play, triple play, and home run.

Name: MIG (volym 3)
Description:
A traditional quiz game in Swedish.

Two dice are rolled, one to decide category and one to decide if you have a 'MIG-chance'. The first player to correctly answer a 'MIG-chance' in each category is the winner.

The questions come in 5 categories: 'Now & Then', 'Culture & Showbiz', 'Home & Away', 'Sports & All sorts' and 'Nature & Science'.

The game contains 1560 questions.

Name: UFO Red Alert
Description:
"Commander Straker has just about the toughest job on this planet - defending Earth for our safety. Now here's your chance to match your skill against the menacing UFO'S. The game can be played by two to seven people. One person takes the role of Straker and defends the Earth by shooting down the UFO's while the other one to six players divide the UFO's between them and try to land on Earth."

The game included a 29 x 19 inch tri-fold game board, an instruction sheet, six UFO pieces, five earth defense ships, and a die. The game came in a black soft plastic folder rather than a box.

Name: Richard Petty Grand National Champion Race Game
Description:
"A hilarious, family fun game for up to six players of all ages. It combines the grand sport of competitive racing with total craziness, for a race you will never forget."

"No player has an advantage no matter what their age. Just because you are ahead, it doesn't mean you will win the race. You may be within half a lap of winning and be sent to the pits, by your best friend; or you may be cruising along minding your own business when some blockhead behind you involves you in an accident and WACKO! off to the pits you both go; or you may draw the dreaded 'Blown Engine' card and be put out of the race."

"There are 30 'fate' cards you may have to draw from -- some are good, some are bad, and some are downright awful. No one is safe from the 'fickle finger of fate', so don't get mad -- get even!!"

Components: game board, six miniature race cars, thirty fate cards, two standard dice, twenty-four green lap chips, twenty-four yellow lap chips, and an instruction sheet.

Name: Dog Eat Dog
Description:
Dog Eat Dog is an abstract strategy game similar to (but entirely different from) RISK using Icehouse pyramids as the playing pieces, and any flat surface as the battlefield.

Players compete to capture opponents' pieces and have the highest score at the end of the game.

On your turn, you may attack any opponent's pyramids with a pyramid of your own. The higher the value of your pyramid, the more dice you get to roll. Highest individual die roll wins that attack.

Rules Link

Game System

    Icehouse Pieces

Name: Boer War
Description:
"Boer War: The Second Boer War (1899-1900)"

A small-press, low to moderate complexity operational wargame covering the turn of the century conflict in South Africa. Originally titled 1899. The game includes special rules for sieges, forced marches, disease, and leaders. The components include a 17x24 inch mapsheet, rulebook, charts and tables, and counters (to be cut apart.)

Name: Maximus
Description: In Maximus players try to place the best drivers in chariots, who then  try to win a race in the Circus Maximus. Players also bet on the chariots, either their own or other players'. Players also compete for the favors of the senators and try to cause collisions between chariots. The player who ends up with the most profit wins the game.

Name: Corner
Description:
Corner is a strategic game of wits and luck.

This game basically allows players to engage in a "battle" to eliminate the other player's pieces. Each players would have 4 warriors (pieces) and 3 chances of regeneration (By territory marking).

This game is card driven as all the pieces are determined and planned by cards in the hand. Cards consist of power card that has special effects and normal cards of movement such as left 3. For power cards, cards (on the hand) has to be paid as tribute to activate the effects, hence having the resource hand management mechanism. Every players would have Start Phase, Play Phase, (Intercept Play phase for people to intercept with Fast Power Cards), Draw phase and End phase. Cards on hand are drawn randomly, hence having the circumstantial luck element.

This game basically trains spatial awareness 
(very directional oriented), brain reaction time, logic and sensory skill.

Name: When My Ship Comes In
Description: "A simple game for young people." This antique game comes in a small box with a colorful picture of a sailing ship on the cover. Components consist of a sheet of rules and four sets of different colored paper slips (referred to as "cards" in the rules.) The players play a set of three types of cards (Wishes, Whence Expected, and When Expected) and the dealer plays a Consequences card on each set.

Name: Shirtsleeves to Shirtsleeves
Description:
Shirtsleeves to Shirtsleeves is an educational boardgame developed by GenSpring Family Offices, a wealth management firm. Its purpose is to encourage intergenerational discussions of wealth management within families. The game name comes from the saying, "From shirtsleeves to shirtsleeves in three generations," meaning that a family fortune earned in one generation can easily be lost by another.

This game was featured on the news radio program "Marketplace" and a version of the story can be found online here: http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2008/06/25/shirtsleeves_to_shirtsleeves/

A summary of gameplay, excerpted from the "Marketplace" report:

"Every player starts with $25 million in play money and from there the game is kind of a cross between Monopoly and the game Life. You roll the die and move your piece along a snaky row of squares in the shape of a dollar sign...every turn, you have to draw a card...Everyone starts in generation one and after a few turns...You enter generation two and then three and there's a separate deck of cards for each."

According to the report, GenSpring is coming out with an advanced version of Shirtsleeves to Shirtsleeves that will let players control the outcome of the game.

Name: Agricola Z-Deck
Description:
The Agricola Z-Deck is a 24-card Promo Deck for Agricola.

It was developed in 2007 by Uwe Rosenberg, Hanno Girke, Melissa Rogerson, and Klemens Franz as a bonus for the first printing of Z-Man games English edition of Agricola, but was also released in other languages. Later Z-Man editions do not contain the Z-Deck.

It comprises 12 Occupation and 12 Minor Improvement cards.

Name: Pendulum
Description:
Pendulum is a simple action game for 2 players, each with 7 wooden cylindrical playing pieces (1.25 inches tall).  These pieces are placed upright on the wooden playing board (15 x 7 inches), at the center of which there is a pendulum made of a one inch diameter wooden ball affixed to a 10 inch long string.  Players take turns pulling back the ball and letting go it, allowing it to free-swing in any direction around the board.   A player wins the round by knocking over the opponent's 7 pieces before all of one's own pieces are knocked over by the pendulum.

Variants described in the instruction booklet include St. Louie ("The Pendulum Dice Game"), Tower Tumble (noncompetitive), and Bowling.

Pendulum has a small 16 page instruction booklet which includes 14 black and white photos, most of young children playing the game.  There is one picture (from about 1900) of an outdoor game of 'quilles', described as "an early pendulum game developed in France in the 14th century."

According to the booklet, Pendulum's "composition is of a Folk Toy Style."   Its board design is "taken from a 12th century A.D. Jain Temple at Kathiawar built to honor Patala, a land devoted to games."

The game book is attributed to Anne Rivers and Carl Chase.  The game and package design are attributed to Carl Chase.  Pendulum was distributed in the mid-1980's by Pinocchio's, located in Kalamazoo, Michigan.

Name: les 7 sages
Description:
Box contents: a 15×15 board, 7 red square pawns and 7 red square pawns representing the wise men, 1 big red pawn representing the fool.

Each player uses his and his opponent's wise men in order to push  the fool into his opponent’s base lines. The wise men moves like chess queen. Once pushed by a wise man, the fool bounces upon the other wise men at right angle.

Name: Hey You in the Jail!
Description:
"Rules for Small Scale Battles in the American West, 1850-1890."

A 23 page rulebook of old west skirmish rules (20-100 figures on each side) designed for use with the 15mm Peter Pig Wild West miniature figures.

Name: Funda
Description:
From the box "FUNDA, a game of chance in which you travel into the exciting history of Black America, earning your way through the University of Black Studies. The first player to earn an Associate Degree, Bachelor’s Degree, Master’s Degree, and finally a Doctorate Degree, wins the game."

Players answer trivia questions as they travel around the board in a roll-and-move mechanism. As players succeed at each "educational" level, they graduate to the next inner board track.

Name: Centennial Presidential Game
Description:
From the publisher's catalog: "These are large and showy games new in plan and style. Played with an indicator... 56 cards giving the Presidents and Vice Presidents of the U.S. with other useful data... Color numbers and pairs the basis of the game... Essentially very different from anything on our list... An instructive novelty."

This antique card game was produced to coincide with the United States' Centennial. In came in a colorfully illustrated 4.5 x 7.5 inch box. The components included a set of 56 cards (each marked with the name of a President or Vice President and historical data), a spinner, and four numbered sheets (two red and two blue with numbers marked in a 3 x 4 grid.)

The unusual spinner, referred to as an "indicator", was marked with the numbers 1 to 6 and had two spinning arrows. The publisher was apparently particularly proud of this component, as indicated by the information printed on the back of it:

"McLoughlin Bros.' Indicator. A Complete and Unobjectionable Substitute for, and Improvement Upon Dice, Teetotums, &c. It's various uses. 1st--As a substitute for Dice, spin the Arrows, and play with the numbers at the points of both Arrows. 2d--As a substitute for Teetotums, use the number at the point of the black Arrow only. NOTE--Should an Arrow stop on a line, both Arrows should be spun again."

Name: Christian's Journey
Description: A game inspired by John Bunyan's book Pilgrim's Progress. The object of the game is to be the first player to reach Celestial City. To do so a player must correctly answer questions about the Bible.

Name: Brigade de recherches
Description:
Box contents: 1 board, 48 “clue” cards, 4 “chief of brigade” pawns, 4 “gendarme pawns”, 4 declaration notebooks (each describing 8 criminal cases), 4 “memento” cards, 12 “witness clue” tokens.
The 12 witness clues are set upon their board spaces, then the players moves their chief and gendarme in order to collect the six clues of their criminal case, and to get back first to their headquarters.

Name: Speed Grammar
Description:
Publisher's description: "Kids love Speed Grammar's three fun bingo-style games that reinforce nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, pronouns, and prepositions."

"Spin the shaker and race to find the correctly color-coded sentence. 'I found a sentence with a red noun, blue verb, orange adjective, and green preposition.' Speed Grammar quickly builds grammar and reading skills as students make matches."

"Colorful cards, unique game shakers, and fast-paced game play offer a hands-on alternative to traditional grammar worksheets. Perfect for learning centers. Includes 3 game shakers, 12 double-sided cards, and 50 game markers. For 2 to 4 players. Grades 3 and up."

Name: A Frog He Would A Wooing Go
Description:
A children's game based on the poem of the same name. "The Object of the game is to see which player who represents the Froggie can avoid being gobbled up by Lily White Duck." The components consist of 47 cards and a box (with the rules on the inside of the lid.)

Each player, in turn, randomly draws a card from the hand of an adjacent player. If the card makes a pair with another card in the player's hand, the pair is played to the center of the table. This continues until all of the pairs have been played. The player left holding the Lily White card is considered to have been gobbled up.

Name: Head to Head Perfection
Description:
Head To Head Perfection Family Action Game
2 Players compete in a race against time!

For 2 players age 8 and up (no batteries needed)

Equipment:
Game console with timer, start/stop switch, 2 pop-up trays and 2 pop bars, and 50 geometric shapes (25 each color).

The Object:
To be the first to place your 25 shapes over their matching forms on the pop-up tray before time runs out.

First one done hits the pop-up bar to pop the other's tray!
Families: Versions & Editions: Two-Player Versions of More-Player Games

Name: Tokyo (fan expansion for On the Underground)
Description: Because of nature of Tokyo's real metro network, the game taste is a little bit different from mother game.  In the main game, a circular line bonus is critically bigger for the goal.  But, in case of Tokyo map, since there's no real metro-line in northern area which run East-West, circular bonus is very limited.

Name: I Can Count
Description:
Reader's Digest I Can Count
Is a children's educational game that can be played 3 different ways:

Steer Clear!
Be the first to get into the blue area along the TOP of the RIGHT SIDE of the board.

Pick-A-Penny
Be the first to get a dollar in your wallet or purse.

Inch Along To The Circus Tent
Be the first to get to the circus tent.

Includes:
Tall Chart to hang on a door or on your wall.
Red and blue magic crayons.
25 dollar bills.
A box to keep your money in.
A box to keep your number bars in.
6 Supermarket shopping cart tokens.
A 12" ruler
Let's count frame with 32 number bars.
2 Sheets of red sticky back markers for your tall chart.
$14.20 in coins.
60 Game cards.
48-Page playbook.
24-Page parent's guide.
20"x35" Gameboard.

Name: Pilgrim's Progress
Description: A "spin and move" board game based on John Bunyan's book Pilgrim's Progress. The board is marked with events from the book, and certain squares have special results. The components include a mounted game board, a spinner, a rulebook, and six colored pawns. The spinner is unusual in that it has three separate concentric circles for results.

Name: Century of Glory
Description:
"A Simulation Study of Operational Warfare from 1840-1900."

A set of rules for wargaming miniature battles from the second half of the nineteenth century. The rulebook includes army lists for many wars from the last half of the nineteenth century, making the rules suitable for a variety of situations ranging from Colonial Conflicts to the American Civil War to the Franco Austrian War of 1859. Each figure represents 40 men, so the rules are suitable for use with 5-25mm scale miniatures.

Publication date is approximate.

Name: The Peanut Race
Description: An antique board game for two, three or four players. The game consisted of a 10x10 inch box and 24 wooden pawns (divided equally into four different colors.) The instructions are printed inside the box cover. The bottom half of the box serves as the game board. The playing area is a circle divided into four pie-shaped quadrants, each of which has six holes into which the pawns may be inserted.

Name: Ting-A-Ling Chimes
Description:
An antique dexterity game from Parker Brothers. The playing board contained inside the box bottom consisted of nine inverted metal bells of varying sizes marked with scores from 25 to 100. Using  five small metal balls and a spring-arm catapult, the object was to score the most point by flinging the balls into the higher scoring bells.

The colorful box cover shows three dogs playing the game. The rules are printed inside the lid. The game also included a small advertising insert for other Parker Brothers games.

Name: Ya-Lo, The Football Card Game
Description:
"A Thrill on Every Play. New Thrills in Every Game. Easy to Play. Realistic Football for Real Fans."

This vintage football card game was originally released in the mid-twenties. A 1940 edition, marked on the box cover as the "New Collegiate Edition", was used to prepare the following description. The limited information located regarding the twenties edition indicates that it may have been self-published, but otherwise it is believed to be similar to the later edition.

The 1940 New Collegiate Edition consists of a box, a 16 3/4 x 9 3/4 inch football-field board (a box bottom insert), 55 Offensive cards, 55 Defensive cards, individual card boxes for these two sets of cards, 29 Time-Out cards, a metal football marker, a cardboard "10-Yard Marker" and the rules.  Note that there are are tracks on the board for keeping track of the four quarters and four downs, so there may have been additional markers to place on these tracks.

The board depicts a 100-yard football field, marked in one yard increments. The 10-Yard marker is used to determine when enough yardage has been gained for a first down. The metal ball is used to mark the field position of the ball. Movement of the ball up and down the field is determined by the Offensive and Defensive cards.

The 1925 set does not contain Time-Out cards, or mention of time-outs in the rules.  The separate board does not have any tracks for quarters or downs.  In addition to the Rules, it includes four pages of "Help for the Novice", a summary of the current NCAA football rules.

Name: Objetivo
Description:
A game of questions and answers with the themes: Geography, Sports, Music, History of Brazil and Trivia.

These are two teams with up to four players. Each team draws a letter goal, the letter shows how many questions the team need to hit, a certain subject, get to eliminate a player of the opponent team.

To each question sure the team wins a victory for the charter issue.

When one stage of your goal is met, you eliminate a player of the opponent team.

The team that eliminated all players of the opponent wins the game.

Name: Maantie
Description:
Description in the back of the box:

"Maantie [Highway] is an easily adopted dice game, where combining the spot counts and summation skills are the key to victory. Maantie is an excellent way to train mental arithmetics and thus has long been the dice game favourite of the young.

Abroad Maantie is known as Matterhorn, which is also played as a gambling game."

The idea of the game is to get all the numbers from 1 to 12 and back to 1, in order, by a single die or by combining multiple dice.

Maantie includes three dice, a scratch pad with scoring tracks, the rules and a pen.

To be precise, 'Maantie is NOT Matterhorn as the publisher claims. There is a slight difference in the rules. Instead, Maantie is better known as Centennial, Ohio or Martinetti.

Name: Sedmiměstí
Description:
Game is played in the country "SedmimÄ›stí" ("Seven-cities"). There are six ordinary cities on the board and one magic - The seventh. Goal of the game is reach the magic city which is located on an island in the middle of the board. To get into the magic city you need to know names of three magic items.

It's a game of fun and parody, combining strategic games and RPG. Very quick game setup.

Box contents:
- 1 colorful board 60 x 60 cm in two variants
- 21 hero cards
- 25 fortune cards (magic items and beings)
- 33 encounter cards
- 3 six-sided dice
- 33 plastic card stands
- 1 list of magic items
- rules

Name: The Passage
Description:
The Passage: The Ultimate Bible Game

(c)2003 NewVentions, Inc.

This is an educational religion game. Players move out from the "Cradle of Creation" and travel through the world as they witness to various countries by using "Passage" cards.

Includes a colorful board, spinner, rules, reference guide, tokens, "Spiritual Gift" dice, cards, timers, missionaries, "Offering" money, plastic stands, and storage insert.

Ages 8 and up.

Name: Rorke's Drift: Tenir ou Mourir
Description:
translated as  HOLD OR DIE

Printed in  Vae Victis #79

This small game simulates one action in the Anglo-Zulu War, the desperate battle at Rorke's Drift (1879), a field hospital manned by 110 hale men guarding 30 wounded and with 20,000 bullets.  By the time the combat was over 10 hours later, 400 Zulu lay dead and they had not been able to break the spirit of the defenders.  This battle restored the honour of the British army and earned the defenders eleven Victoria Crosses, Britain's greatest award for military valour.  This number for a single battle has not been surpassed to this day.

The game concentrates exclusively on the defense of the hospital (western portion).  It has few counters, a single page map which represents the western approach and the hospital, and two pages of rules.  It has three scenarios which all deal with protecting the wounded (they are represented by counters).

Components must be mounted.

Name: Hvad er det værd?
Description: How much is it worth? is a game based on the danish tv-program also called How much is it worth?. It's a game where you place a bid on antique products that have been found in places in Denmark. You should also pick-up tiles and select 3 of a kind.

Name: Hexum
Description:
"Puzzling with letters"

Hexum is a word game, where the letters are connected like a puzzle. The challenge of the game is to puzzle with the letters to form the longest words.
The hexagonal shape of the letters makes it possible to form words not just in a straight line, but in a line that twists and loops over the board, like a snake.
The longer the words the more points you'll get. But each turn you'll only get two new letters.
The kings on the scoreboard keep track of the score. They also interfere with each other. They can push each other back on the scoreboard.
The king that reaches the end first is the winner.

For more information visit: http://www.magi-games.nl/hex/index_hex.html (Dutch)

Name: Cape Cod Treasure
Description:
AT THE BEACH, IN THE CAR,OR AT HOME...

...this game is for anyone who loves Cape Cod, but especially for those who are looking for a fun way to explore the Cape and experience it as they never have before. As you meander around the map, you'll be asked questions, like any trivia game, but the answers lead to wonderful little-known beaches and natural areas, local legends and language, working farms and festivals, historic sites, golf courses, colorful establishments and more, all of which are waiting to be enjoyed every day in towns all over the Cape and islands if you know where to look.

Name: Maze Craze
Description:
Maze Craze is an abstract strategy game for 2 players (or for 4 playing as two teams).  Each player has 8 plastic playing piece pawns initially lined up on opposite sides of an 8x8 square space game board.  A turn consists of moving one playing piece one space and then following "the directions indicated by the symbol on that square."  These directions include: Move Again, Advance, Safe, Defense, Return to Start.  The winner is the first player to move all of one's own 8 playing pieces to the other side of the board.

Game rules are printed on one small sheet of paper, English on one side and French on the other, but the board is English only.

Name: Kubus Fugus
Description:
Kubus Fugus consists of 30 wooden cubes (4 cm / 1.6 inch). Each cube has the same 6 different patterns on its sides, but no two cubes have the same arrangement of these six sides. The sides have dots or lines in different patterns, carved into the wooden surfaces.

Each player "owns" a type of side, e.g. the "cross" or the "four dots" and places one cube on his turn onto the 5 x 6 grid board, starting from a corner. There are only a few rules:

1. Placing a cube, the sides surface-to-surface to another cube has to have the same pattern.

2. This also applies, if the cube has to fit in between two or three cubes already placed, thus limiting the possibilities.

3. It is forbidden to place a cube in a way, that an adjacent cube cannot be placed. SO, sides facing a "spare" place are not allowed to be the same.

4. There may not occur any "holes" on the board, so the whole grid is filled up slowly.

Since you have to draw your next cube randomly, there is a "luck factor", for the limitations in placement can be huge or non-existent.

Scoring:
If the grid is filled up - or cannot be filled any further - the sides showing upside are counted for each player. The player with the most sides showing up is the winner.

There are a lot of puzzles, too, for the 1-player-variant, and 3D-variants.

One special thing about this game is, that you can also play it blindfold or with blind people.

Name: Always in Motion
Description:
From the box:
"Vehicles that travel through air, in the sea and on land... Match the mode of transportation to its medium! Match the cards to the boards in a lotto game of photographs!"

Contents:
4 game boards (park, street, air, water).
24 game cards (6 for each board representing a different vehicle with a picture and name).

This game is for children ages 2 to 5. The rules list two ways to play, a "Lotto" game and a "Memory" game.

In the "Lotto" game each player receives a board. Players take turns drawing a card and comparing the vehicle on the card to the vehicles on the player's board. Matching cards are placed on the corresponding board space. The winner is the first player to cover all six spaces on their board.

The "Memory game is played by first choosing a dealer. The dealer gives each player a board. The players study their board for one minute then turn them face down. The dealer shows the top card to all the players. If a player thinks it matches a vehicle on their board they say "Mine" and place the card next to their board. This continues until all the cards have been shown. The players turn their boards face up. For each matching card a player earns 1 point. For each non-matching card a player looses 2 points. The winner is the player with the most points.

Name: The Raleigh Cruising Game
Description: British promotional cycling game published by the Raleigh Cycle Company just after their 50 year existence.
